Yes, that's right, when I mentioned the success of pole balancing with
a sm=
all population size, I am measuring performance by # evaluations.
 However,=
 note that # evaluations is a more appropriate measure than #
generations. =
 If you take 100 generations with a population of 10,
that takes far less e=
ffort than 10 generations with a population of
1,000.  It's the # of evalua=
tions that counts (and that is also how
performance is measured in machine =
learning in general: # evaluations
to success).

My dissertation points out=
 the dramatic difference in # evaluations to
solve pole balancing between n=
ormal population sizes and tiny
population sizes.  This fact also shows why=
 pole balancing is a
misleading benchmark:  Population size probably eclips=
es any other
factor in correlating with performance, which means any method=
 can be
made to look better by simply dropping the population size.  

ken
